title: Figma Buzz Adds Three Power Features to Help Brands Move Faster and Stay On-Brand

paragraphs.content: Figma has rolled out three major upgrades to Figma Buzz aimed at making it easier for marketing and brand teams to ship high-volume, on-brand content without bottlenecks.The update introduces configurable templates built directly on design systems, enabling marketers to swap layouts and options without wading through hundreds of static variants.Buzz now also supports plugins inside the app, extending workflows for digital asset management, translation, animation, and more.Rounding out the release, new video trimming tools let teams refine clips on the fly, so social and campaign assets can hit exact time and platform requirements without leaving Buzz.

paragraphs.content: By tying templates to component properties, Figma is positioning Buzz as a scalable “brand-safe content factory” where designers set the guardrails and marketers self-serve within them.Industry watchers note that this closes a key gap between design systems and everyday marketing execution, particularly for organizations that need tight brand consistency across regions and channels.The arrival of plugins in Buzz also brings it deeper into existing martech stacks, from localization pipelines to asset libraries and motion workflows. Together with built-in video trimming, these changes signal Figma’s intent to compete more directly with Canva-style tools while leaning on its core strength: systematized, reusable design.

sections.title: Configurable, Design-System-Powered Templates Cut Through Template Sprawl

paragraphs.content: At the center of the update are configurable templates that inherit structure and rules from a team’s design system via component sets and component properties.Designers can define layout options, color schemes, ratios, and show/hide controls in Figma Design, then send those templates to Buzz where the same properties remain editable but brand-safe.In practice, marketers can switch a campaign asset from horizontal to vertical, toggle logos or illustrations, or apply seasonal variants without detaching components or rebuilding layouts.Figma’s own walkthrough stresses that content edits persist as users swap layouts, making it easy to generate multiple channel-specific variants from a single base asset.

paragraphs.content: The new “Change layout” panel in Buzz exposes those component-driven options as visual thumbnails and simple toggles or dropdowns, so non-designers can browse and configure layouts without touching the underlying system.Help Center guidance emphasizes that some templates now arrive as sets, with each layout appearing individually in the picker while still remaining part of a unified, configurable family.Design system experts argue this reduces template sprawl—replacing dozens of near-duplicate files with a single, parameterized template set that is easier to maintain and update.When designers republish a template set, Buzz surfaces a clear “update available” prompt, letting collaborators compare changes side by side and accept or ignore them, which helps manage brand evolution over time.

sections.title: Plugins and Video Trimming Bring Marketing Workflows Directly Into Buzz

paragraphs.content: Beyond templates, Figma Buzz now embeds plugin support so teams can run tools for digital asset management, translation, animation, and other specialized tasks without leaving the canvas.Organizations can also build and publish internal plugins, tailoring Buzz to their specific brand and marketing workflows—from pulling the latest approved imagery to automating regional copy swaps.Coverage from Config 2025 recaps notes that motion and animation plugins are particularly valuable, since they let marketers add movement and polish to assets using the same environment where templates live. Analysts say this extensibility is a key differentiator for Buzz, giving enterprises the control and integration depth they often miss in consumer-focused content tools.

paragraphs.content: The addition of native video trimming further tightens Buzz’s grip on the marketing production pipeline, allowing users to cut clips to specific durations and sync multiple videos directly inside their layouts.Figma’s release notes highlight that this is designed for everyday scenarios like tailoring a single campaign video to different social placements or trimming event footage into snackable promos.Community roundups point out that, previously, teams had to juggle external editors for even simple trims, adding friction and version risk to otherwise straightforward updates. With configurable templates, plugins, and inline video control now in place, commentators expect Figma to continue deepening Buzz’s integrations and automation features, pushing closer to an end-to-end system for brand content creation and management.
